execution_summary: Built a Python 3.10 Docker image with pandas, numpy, scipy, statsmodels, and pyreadstat. Started the container, detected a missing Python entrypoint, and created analysis/obrien_lca_replication__py.py translating the Stata .do (cleaning, listwise deletion, 3-class LCA via EM with optional weights, class labeling, and focal t-tests). Previewed the entry and obtained human approval. First execution failed due to pandas.read_stata not supporting the Stata file version; patched the script to use pyreadstat.read_dta and retried. The analysis then ran successfully, producing results and class profiles. No deviations from the planned hypothesis test occurred; the focal contrast (Post-secular vs Traditional on evolution acceptance) was tested across (a) >2010, (b) all years, and (c) <=2010 subsets.

results.hypothesis_tested: Respondents with a post-secular perspective are less likely than respondents with a traditional perspective to accept evolution (evolved_clean = 1).

findings_summary.outcome_name: Difference in evolution acceptance (Post-secular − Traditional), subset > 2010
findings_summary.effect_size: Welch t-stat = -20.75; Means: Post-secular 0.0322, Traditional 0.4089; Ns: 528 vs 895

findings_summary.outcome_name: Difference in evolution acceptance (Post-secular − Traditional), subset All years
findings_summary.effect_size: Welch t-stat = -26.72; Means: Post-secular 0.0356, Traditional 0.3449; Ns: 1153 vs 2169

findings_summary.outcome_name: Difference in evolution acceptance (Post-secular − Traditional), subset ≤ 2010
findings_summary.effect_size: Welch t-stat = -19.18; Means: Post-secular 0.0259, Traditional 0.3066; Ns: 657 vs 1210

tables.table_description: Latent class sizes and profile metrics (knowledge mean, evolution acceptance rate, bible literalist rate) for each subset used for data-driven class labeling.
Subset-wise Welch t-tests and two-proportion z-tests for Post-secular vs Traditional groups on evolved_clean.
